Translated by Dharma Master Fa Sheng of Gaochang, Northern Liang Dynasty
Thus have I heard:

Once, the Buddha was traveling in the country of GandhÄra, in the great city of VaiÅ›ravaá¹‡a, under the shade of a mountain cliff to the north of the city, expounding the Dharma and teaching the king, ministers, and people, as well as the eight groups of spiritual beings, humans, and non-humans, delivering countless people.
When the teaching and transformation were about to end, the Buddha smiled, and fragrant light emerged from his mouth. The light had nine colors and illuminated all the countries;
The fragrance was also like that.
At that time, the great assembly, seeing the light and smelling the fragrance, all greatly rejoiced.
Then, the light circled the Buddha seven times and entered back into his mouth.
At that time, Ä€nanda adjusted his robes, knelt for a long time with his palms joined, and said to the Buddha:
Now the World-Honored One has manifested wondrous auspicious signs, which must have causes and conditions, benefiting many, and sentient beings will be blessed.
I only wish that the Heavenly Venerable would explain the causes and conditions.
The Buddha told Ä€nanda:
As you have said, the secret words of the Buddhas, and all the manifested signs, have great causes and conditions. Do you wish to hear them?
Ä€nanda said:
Yes!
Only the Heavenly Honored One!
The Buddha told Ä€nanda:
In the past, nine kalpas ago, there was no Buddha in the world.
There was a great country called Gandhamati, the king was named Gandhasri, the queen was named Chamukha, and the prince was named Chandana.
The country was vast, prosperous, and had many people, with a human lifespan of 1,500 years.
The prince was virtuous, and the world was at peace, with no thieves or robbers, and the people were harmonious and did not fight with each other.
The prince was kind, wise, and intelligent, and he mastered all the scriptures and 96 kinds of arts and etiquette, and there was nothing he did not understand;
From a young age, he always enjoyed giving, sparing no effort in body, life, or wealth;
He nurtured beings with greater love than for his own children, his great compassion universally covering all equally without distinction, and he was filial to his parents, observing all propriety.
At that time, the king, the father, built a garden outside the city not far from the prince.
The garden was eight yojanas wide and long, planted with various flowers and fruits, with rare birds and exotic animals, pure and beautifully adorned;
Everywhere there were flowing springs and bathing pools, in which always grew blue, red, and white lotuses, as well as other various kinds of red and white lotus flowers;
Peacocks, geese, pheasants, and mandarin ducks played within, cool and refreshing, fragrant and pure, supremely wonderful.
At that time, the prince, together with the ministers, officials, consorts, and court ladies, went to the garden for amusement, returning to the palace after seven days.

At that time, in the kingdom, there were poor, orphaned, and elderly people with a hundred illnesses. Hearing that the prince had returned, they all came to the side of the road, stretching out their hands towards the prince.
Seeing this, the prince immediately gave away his body ornaments, clothing, gold coins, silver coins, carriages, elephants, and horses, all as offerings;
when he reached the city gate, he had nothing left, but the poor were still many, and he regretted not being able to satisfy them all.
When the prince returned to the palace, he thought of the poor people and was so worried he could not eat.
The king asked the prince:
'What are you upset about?'
The prince replied:

'Recently, while going out for a stroll, I saw poor people on the side of the road, begging for what they lacked. I immediately gave them everything I had, but it was still not enough, so I am worried myself.
Now I wish to ask the great king for the middle treasury's wealth to distribute to the world. I wonder if the great king will grant my wish?'
The king said:
'The state's treasury is for preparing against emergencies. It should not be used privately.'
Thus the prince's wish was not fulfilled, and his sorrow was doubled.
A minister of the prince named Jaya, seeing that the prince was not eating, was sorrowful and distressed.
He knelt for a long time with his hands clasped and said to the prince:
'I have ten thousand gold coins to offer to the great god, to be used as you wish. I wish you would not worry about poverty. Eat and drink as before;
if the money is not enough, I will sell myself to serve the great god.'
Then Jaya immediately offered ten thousand gold coins to the prince.
The prince had someone take the money out of the city to give to the poor, but even with ten thousand coins it was still not enough.
He returned and said to the prince:
'The gold coins are all used up, but there are still many poor people.

Thereupon, the prince immediately ordered a side minister to inspect his private treasury, and he obtained another ten thousand gold coins, which he gave to the poor people, but it was still not enough.
The prince thought to himself:
The suffering of people is all due to poverty and the suffering of not being able to obtain what they seek.
Now I should sell my beloved body to save others from suffering and enable them to attain peace and happiness.
Having contemplated this, he put away his precious clothes, put on ordinary old clothes, silently left the palace city, went to another country called Paeti Sha,
and sold himself to a Brahmin, obtaining a thousand gold coins, which he used to give to the poor people.
At that time, the Brahmin made his slave drive a cart into the mountains to cut firewood, which he sold in the market;
after many days, he later went to collect firewood and obtained a piece of ox-head sandalwood in the mountains, weighing one hundred catties.
At that time, the king of that country originally had a leprosy disease, and medical prescriptions and spells could not cure it.
The king became angry and said:
What use are these doctors?
All the hundreds of illnesses have corresponding medicines to treat them, so why is my illness the only one that is not cured?
He ordered the doctors to be arrested and executed in the marketplace.
At that time, a doctor kowtowed to the king and said:
The medicine that treats the king's illness is difficult to find in the world. Although it has a name, it has never been seen.
The king said:
What is the name of the medicine?
He replied:
It is called ox-head sandalwood.
The king said:
The karmic actions of people's sins and merits are not the same. There may be a person with merit who has this medicine.
He then ordered an announcement throughout the country, saying: Whoever has this medicine, I will give them half the country in exchange for it.
At that time, the brÄhman called his slave and said:
Although you have earned a little money by selling firewood, it is not as profitable as this rich and noble gain:
The king of the country has a disease, and now he wants to use half of the country to buy ox-head sandalwood.
You can now take this sandalwood and offer it to the great king. You will surely get what you want. I will share this joy with you.'
Then the slave took the ox-head sandalwood and offered it to the king of the country.
After the king received it, he ground it and applied it to his body, and his leprosy was cured.

The king was greatly delighted, and the entire country and its people all benefited from the celebration. He immediately summoned the ministers to hold a great assembly, pardoned prisoners, gave alms to the poor, and brought peace and joy to all.

The king ordered a great minister to divide half of the palace, as well as the people he ruled, gold, silver, treasures, money, grain, silk, slaves, carriages, elephants, horses, cows, and sheep, all of which were divided in half;
He adorned a hundred jeweled carriages and a thousand horses, with singing and music, incense, flowers, banners, and a hundred kinds of food and drink to welcome the slave back to the country.
The king then invited him to sit together on a jeweled bed, and they enjoyed music, food, and entertainment.
The king asked the slave:
I see that your blessings, virtues, and majestic appearance are extraordinary in the world. For what reason are you in a lowly position? I wish to hear your aspirations.
The slave said:
Very good!
If you wish to hear, I shall now speak.
As you suspect, I am not originally a slave.
Have you ever heard of the prince named Candanadatta, the son of the king of Gandhamati, who loved to give generously?
He replied:
I have heard of him many times, but I have never seen him.
He said:
I am he.
When the king heard this, he doubled his respect and said:
For what reason did this happen?
The prince said:

I loved to give generously, and the wealth of the country was not enough to meet the needs. The poor were still many, and my original vow was not fulfilled. Therefore, I abandoned the country and sold myself.
The king said:
'Your past actions have led to the retribution of suffering. Cultivating goodness brings happiness, while doing evil leads to suffering.
This is not something you have done, nor is it given by your parents. Why do you go against the great hopes of the country and engage in dangerous and difficult endeavors?
Such things are rare in the world. There must be a different perspective. Please explain your thoughts.'
The prince replied:
'I originally made a vow to deliver all beings, practice the perfections, and aspire to attain enlightenment.'
The king said:
'Excellent!
I rejoice greatly.'
The prince said to the king:
'I now return the country to you, but I only ask for one wish, which I hope you will not go against.'
He replied:
'What is the wish?'
The prince said:

'I wish to obtain the treasures in the treasury and distribute them to the poor, orphans, the elderly, the weak, and those with a hundred illnesses throughout the world. I will give freely for fifty days, and the merit from this I will share with you.'
The king said:
Very good!
The money and property are for you to use as you wish. Half the country that I reward is your share of the merit. I dare not accept it.
The prince said:
Good!
You give me wealth, and I offer the country to you.
I like giving, and you like the country. The people and surnames are different, and our aspirations are not the same.
The king said:
This practice is vast and profound, not something I can reach.
When you attain the Way, I pray that you will save me.
The prince then sent messengers to proclaim to all countries, saying, 'If there are any poor, orphaned, old, and infirm people, all are to be gathered.'

At that time, the prince had people open the storehouses, transport the wealth and goods to the flat ground, and give them to the poor people for fifty days. The poor became rich and were all delighted.
At that time, after the prince left the country, the ministers were frightened and wept, saying to the king:
'Last night, the prince suddenly disappeared and we do not know where he is.'
When the king heard these words, he fell off his bed and was confused, not recognizing anyone.

The prince's wife, the palace ladies, concubines, ministers, officials, and people were all shocked, saddened, and distressed. They cried out in grief and ran in all directions searching for the prince.

At that time, the prince's wife, fearing she had lost her son, was agitated and frantic, like a mad person. She immediately pulled up her robe and disheveled her hair, ran out of the city, and chased in all directions searching for the prince.

The king feared that the prince's wife, thinking of her son in distress, might lose her life, so he immediately had his troops and ministers ready and left the city to search for the prince's wife and news of the prince.

Ten miles from the country, in the grass of an empty marsh, he saw the prince's wife, with several palace ladies, beating her chest and crying, her hair disheveled and eyes swollen, searching through the grass, looking for the prince.
When the king saw this, he was even more sorrowful and distressed;
Previously, he held the queen's hand, his tears flowing like rain, and advised the queen, saying:

Our son has blessings and virtues, is kind and filial, and gives to others without resentment. He has given away all his wealth to the world, but it is still not enough. He always feels regret that he has nothing to give.
Our son has secretly left now, and will certainly go to other countries to seek wealth to give in charity, or sell himself to provide for the poor.
Let us return to the palace together, do not be too worried.
I will now send messengers to the various countries to inquire about the news, and we will surely get our son back.
The queen scolded, saying:
It is because the king is stingy and greedy, guarding and cherishing his money and wealth, and does not love his son.
Can the son's body be bought with money and wealth now?
The king said:
My mistake was in the past, what use is there in regretting now?
Let us return to the palace together, and we may not lose our son.
I will now personally go out in all directions to search for him, and must get our son back.
The queen shed tears and said:
'Now that I have lost my son, what is the point of living?
I would rather die here than return home empty-handed.
I observe my son's body, not knowing hunger or thirst. Although he has suffered from illness, I do not consider it a problem. Now returning to an empty house, what can I rely on?'
Then the prince's wife and concubines, with disheveled hair and disoriented, cried out to the heavens, beat their heads on the ground, and looked in the four directions, not seeing the prince;
they cried out to the heavens, beat their heads on the ground, and said while drinking tears:
'The heavens, the earth, the sun, the moon, the spirits of my parents!
If I have committed offenses, I now repent of them all. I wish to be reunited with my husband and son soon.'
Then the king forcefully pulled the prince's wife and concubines, loaded them in a carriage, and returned to the palace.

At that time, the prince was far away in another country. His two eyes, hands, and feet trembled three times. His heart was worried and frightened, as if he had forgotten something. He then took leave of the king and returned to his own country.
The king ordered his ministers to prepare a hundred jeweled carriages, a thousand horses, ten thousand gold coins, and one hundred thousand silver coins.
The king had five hundred great ministers who gave ten thousand gold coins and one hundred thousand silver coins to see the prince off.
The king, together with ten million ministers, saw the prince off at the border, held a great assembly, and happily took leave of each other, then parted ways.
The prince thought to himself:
Since I was young, my feet have never moved recklessly, and my eyes have never glanced around.

When I left the country before without taking leave of my parents, it must have been because my parents and the country's ministers and people were worried and distressed, fearing that they would lose me.
I should go quickly now to let them know the news.
He thought again:
The road is long and far, and I cannot reach there immediately.
I fear that my parents, out of deep sorrow, may lose their lives. What method can I use to quickly convey the news?
At that time, there was a crow that could speak human language. It said to the prince:
Your kindness is extremely heavy, and your grace reaches everywhere. What worries are not resolved?
What do you want to do? I will help you.
The prince replied:
I want to entrust one matter, I hope you will not go against it.
The crow said:
I will obey your orders!
The prince said:
I trouble you to deliver a letter to my father, the king.
The crow said:
You should hurry, now is the right time.
The prince wrote a letter and gave it to the crow. The crow flew back to its own country with the letter in its mouth and placed the letter in front of the king.
The king opened the letter and read it. He knew the news of the prince and was very happy. He immediately got up and entered the palace.
He said to the queen:
Did I tell you? I knew I would not lose my son. In a few days, I will definitely see my son.
When the queen heard this, she was like the dead coming back to life. She clapped her hands and praised:ğŸ”½Excellent!
'May all under Heaven be at peace and happy, may their wishes be fulfilled, and may their lifespans be immeasurable!'
At that time, the ministers, nobles, men, women, and people of all ages in the country heard that the Crown Prince was returning and all exclaimed 'ten thousand years!'
The king then, with many millions of ministers, prepared a carriage and escort to go out and welcome the Crown Prince.
On the road, they met each other. The Crown Prince saw his father and immediately got down from the jeweled carriage, joined his palms, and said to the king:
'My Way is not filial, and I have wasted the divine presence of Your Majesty, alarming the country. I am fortunate to have been forgiven.'
The king said:
'Excellent!'
Father and son saw each other, and sorrow and joy mixed together. They turned the carriage back to the palace, and all the people of the country rejoiced.
The poor and destitute people from distant lands, hearing that the Crown Prince was returning and that many would obtain wealth, all came from afar to beg from the Crown Prince.

The prince had people carry money and goods, and on the level ground at the head of the main road, he gave to the poor people. For a year, he gave daily without interruption, and those who came from the four directions all got what they wished for.
At that time, the father king said to the prince together with the ministers:
'From now on, the precious treasures of the national treasury can be used as needed. Do not hesitate.'
The virtue of giving is valued far and near. Even hateful enemies and evil people who hear of the prince's merits will naturally cultivate goodness.

At that time, there was a sage named Heroic, with five supernatural powers, who was a Taoist practitioner. He was living in a large cave on the mountain with five hundred disciples, cultivating meditation and practicing the Way, aspiring to attain enlightenment and deliver all from suffering, teaching and transforming the world to cultivate goodness.
At that time, Prince Candramati brought various kinds of food and drink of a hundred flavors to the mountain to make offerings to the sages and Taoist practitioners.
At that time, the sage blessed the prince and spoke the Dharma for him.

The prince was delighted in his heart, his aspiration was to be free from worldly affairs, he did not wish to return to the country, he thought of the palace as a place of rebirth in hell, his wife and relatives as shackles, and he viewed the five desires and pleasures as a hell.

Having contemplated this, he immediately untied his necklace and the ornaments on his body, and entrusted the carriage, horses, and attendants to a minister beside him, sending them back to the country.
Then, the prince put on deerskin clothes and stayed in the mountains, following the teacher to study the Way, and diligently sought the path of the Way.
At that time, the prince's attendant returned to the country and reported to the king:
'The prince went up the mountain to make offerings to the sage, stayed there to study the Way, and is unwilling to return to the palace;
he has mastered all the scriptures and spells, and himself will not return.'
The king said:
'How painful!
When worldly people obtain a son, they experience joy and rely on him for old age, to benefit the country and remove troubles.
I have obtained this son, but I am always worried and suffering. He does not desire wealth and status, and does not associate with relatives.
What is the point of this troublesome son?
He then summoned the ministers to discuss this matter together. The ministers said:
The prince is fond of the Way, does not crave worldly glory, and delights in non-action.
Since he does not return to the country, there is nothing that can be done about it.
The king should send an envoy to ascertain his intentions. If he definitely will not return, then measures should be taken accordingly.
The king then sent an envoy to ask the prince:
I now await your return like one who thirsts for water. Why do you linger in the mountains and not return?
Now the first lady and the queen shed tears and look to the road, wailing and distressed, unable to bear it.
A son's way is to be at ease with his parents. You should not be so obstinate.
Follow the envoy and return!
The envoy received the order and said as instructed.
The prince replied:
'All things are impermanent, and forms do not last long. The joy of family and household, when separated, is suffering. Life and death are determined by heaven, and one cannot be independent.
When impermanence arrives, even with father and son, one cannot save the other.
Now seeking the unconditioned, wishing to deliver from all suffering, on the day of attaining the Way, I will first deliver my parents.
This place is not far, I will also go there in time to pay my respects.
My intention is already set, the king should make other plans to continue the succession of the country.'
The messenger returned and reported to the king, explaining the above matters in detail.
The king then summoned all the ministers and established a new crown prince.

At that time, the king's wife, together with the crown prince's consort, maids, and attendants, brought the crown prince's clothes and ornaments, as well as various sweet fruits, food and drink, incense, flowers, and music, leading the way in front and behind, to the mountain where the crown prince was, to feed the assembly of sages.
They then welcomed the crown prince. The wife said:
'Husband and wife plant grain to prevent hunger, dig wells to wait for thirst, build fortifications to prevent thieves, and raise children to serve the elderly.
If you do not return to the country now, my life will not be complete.'
The prince knelt for a long time and said to his wife:
'Abandoning the family to live in the mountains, changing one's appearance and clothing, is like spitting out of the mouth, not suitable for eating.
A recluse has nothing to offer the country.
The principles are already determined, and cannot be changed. I would rather shatter my body here, and never return.

I wish that my mother will return in time, and I will soon come to pay my respects.'ğŸ”½Then the wife and the prince's queen and concubines saw that the prince's intention was firm and had no thought of returning. They wept sorrowfully and returned along the road.

At that time, the king of the country only hoped that his wife would get the prince to return. He went out of the city with the ministers to welcome them, but only saw the wife and the prince's queen and concubines with disheveled hair, beating their chests and crying out, returning along the road in vain.
The king became even more unhappy, and the myriad officials and people all wept tears. They turned the carriage back to the palace.
Then the king apologized to the queen and the wife of the prince:
My son loves the Way, which is difficult to find in the world;
He nurtures with kindness and universally saves, and none do not receive his grace.
He is a treasure of this country, not an ordinary vessel.
Now he happily resides in the mountains, cultivating his aspirations. Just let him be at ease, and we will see each other from time to time.
Now he is not far from his son, so send him food and drink, and let there be news coming and going. This way he can comfort himself.
Then the queen, having received the king's advice, her sorrowful feelings subsided somewhat.
From time to time she sent people to bring food and drink, as well as various sweet fruits and delicious delicacies, to the mountains to make offerings to the prince.
In this way, for many years, the prince also came down from time to time to pay his respects to his parents, and then returned to the mountains to cultivate the Way.
Under the cliff there is a deep valley, at the bottom of which there is a tiger mother who has recently given birth to seven cubs.

At that time, heavy snow fell from the sky, and the tiger mother had been holding her cubs for many days without being able to find food. Fearing that her cubs would freeze to death, she guarded them while starving.
The snow continued to fall without stopping, and the mother and cubs were hungry and exhausted, and their lives would soon be over.
The tiger mother, being tormented by the fire of hunger, wanted to eat her cubs again.
At that time, the immortal practitioners on the mountain saw this and encouraged each other, saying:
Who can give up their body to save sentient beings? Now is the right time.
When the prince heard this, he exclaimed:
Excellent!
My wish has been fulfilled!

He went to the edge of the cliff and looked down. He saw the tiger mother holding her cubs, covered in snow. Feeling great compassion, he stood on the mountain peak in silence and entered concentration, and immediately attained the acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas.
He observed events from countless eons in the past and the future as well.
He then returned to his teacher and the five hundred fellow students and said:
I will now give up my body. I wish you all to rejoice.
The teacher said:
Your study of the Way is still shallow, and your knowledge and insight are not yet extensive. Why do you suddenly want to end your life and abandon your beloved body?
The prince replied:
I made a vow in the past to give up a thousand bodies.
I have already given up nine hundred and ninety-nine bodies. Giving up my body today will complete the thousand bodies.
Therefore, I am giving it up. I wish the teacher will rejoice.
The teacher said:
Your lofty aspirations are unsurpassed.
If you attain the Way first, do not forget me.
The prince took leave of his teacher and departed.
Then the great teacher, together with the five hundred divine practitioners and adepts, with tears filling their eyes, saw the prince to the edge of the mountain cliff.
At that time, the wealthy elder Fu Lan, leading five hundred men and women, brought food and drink to the mountain to make offerings;
Seeing the prince give up his body, they grieved and wept, also following the prince to the edge of the cliff.
Then the prince, in front of the crowd, made a great vow:

I now give up my body to save the lives of the multitude. May I quickly attain enlightenment, attain the vajra body, the body of the Dharma of permanence, bliss, self, and purity, and the unconditioned body. May I liberate those who are not yet liberated, free those who are not yet free, and bring peace to those who are not yet at peace.
This body of mine is impermanent, full of suffering and afflictions.
This body is impure, with nine orifices overflowing with filth, stung by the four poisonous snakes, and pursued and harmed by the five bandits with drawn swords.

Such a body is ungrateful. Delicious delicacies and the pleasures of the five desires are offered to this body, but upon death, there is no good reward or gratitude, and one instead falls into hell to experience immeasurable suffering.
The human body is only meant for suffering, not for pleasure.
The prince reprimanded his body in various ways, and then made a vow, saying:
'Now I will save the starving tigress with my flesh and blood.

As for the remaining bones and relics, my parents will surely build a stupa later, so that all sentient beings who suffer from various illnesses and whose illnesses cannot be cured by medicine, moxibustion, or acupuncture due to the causes and conditions of past sins, will come to the stupa site and make offerings with utmost sincerity. Depending on the severity of the illness, they will surely be cured in no more than a hundred days.
If this is not false, then let the gods rain down fragrant flowers.'
The gods immediately rained down mandara flowers, and the earth trembled.
The prince then untied his deerskin robe and wrapped it around his head, joined his hands, and threw himself in front of the tiger.
Then the tigress ate the Bodhisattva's flesh, and both the mother and cub were saved.

At that time, the people on the cliff looked down and saw that the prince had been devoured by the tiger, with his bones and flesh scattered about. They wailed loudly, their cries shaking the mountain.
Some beat their chests, rolled on the ground, or sat in meditation, while others kowtowed and repented to the prince.

At that time, the ÅšuddhÄvÄsa gods, Åšakra DevÄnÄm-Indra, the Four Heavenly Kings, and the sun and moon gods, in the millions, all gave rise to the intention to achieve supreme enlightenment. They played music, burned incense, scattered flowers, and offered mandÄra flowers to the prince, singing these words:ğŸ”½Excellent!
Great being!
Before long, you will sit at the site of enlightenment.
Having sung this three times, they each returned to their heavenly palaces.
The five hundred sages all gave rise to the intention to achieve supreme, perfect enlightenment, and the great sage attained acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas.
The king and his wife sent messengers the next day to take food and drink to the mountain to provide for the prince.
Arriving at the prince's stone chamber, he only saw the bedding, deerskin robe, umbrella, alms bowl, tin staff, water bottle, and washbasin in the room, but did not see the prince.
He searched everywhere, but no one responded. He only saw the sages crying in groups of ten or fifteen.
Arriving at the great sage's place, he only saw the sage with his hand on his cheek, tears filling his eyes, and sitting there moaning.
He searched all around, but no one responded.
The messenger was frightened and immediately offered food and drink to the sages. He ran back and told the queen the above events in detail.
The queen said:
You did not see my son, but did you see the sages?
He replied:
I only saw the sages crying in groups of ten or fifteen.
The queen said:ğŸ”½Alas!
My son is dead!
She beat her chest and wailed loudly, rushing to the king.
When the king heard this, he fell off his bed, confused and not knowing where he was.
Tens of thousands of ministers and people gathered by the king's side, kowtowed and remonstrated, saying:
We do not know if what the prince did in the mountains is true or not, why are you wailing in grief?
We beg the king to take a moment to rest.
Then the king, together with the queen, consorts, maids, ministers, officials, and people, rolled up their robes, went barefoot, and rushed up the mountain.
At that time, the elder Fu Lan also came back and told the king:
The prince yesterday threw himself off a cliff, using his flesh to feed the tigers. Now only his bones remain, scattered on the ground.
Then the elder led the king to the place where the prince's body was.
The king, queen, consorts, maids, ministers, officials, and people raised their voices in grief, shaking the mountains and valleys.
The king and queen lay on top of the prince's body, their hearts and livers shattered, dazed and not recognizing anyone.
The queen came forward to support his head and comb the prince's hair. Her heart and liver were crushed, and she wailed with a choked voice, saying:
'How unfortunate I am! Born, I lost my lord.
Today, forever cut off, I shall never see him again.
Better to have my body shattered into dust and powder, than to have my heaven suddenly like this now.
Since the prince is already dead, what use do I have for life?'
Then the ministers said to the king:
'The prince, through giving, vowed to deliver all beings, but was taken away by the ghost of impermanence.
Before he rots, we should make offerings.

' They then collected his bones, brought them out of the mountain valley, and on level ground piled sandalwood and various fragrant woods, all kinds of incense, ghee, oil, silk canopies, banners and flags to cremate the prince;
collected his relics and stored them in jeweled vessels. They then built a seven-jeweled pagoda right there, adorning it with various precious objects.
The stupa was ten li on each side, with various flowers and fruits, flowing springs, and bathing pools, all neat and clean.
The king always ordered the four groups of musicians to make offerings day and night and entertain the stupa.
The Buddha told Ananda:
The prince at that time was me;
The father king at that time is now my father, Shuddhodana;
The queen at that time is now Maya;
The queen at that time is now Gopa;
The minister Jaya at that time is now Ananda;
The great immortal master on the mountain at that time is now Maitreya;
King Petishana is now Nanda;
The brahmin at that time is now Rahula.
